channel.title: Making a php site with index.php?action=blahblahblah(Updated)

item.title: Making a php site with index.php?action=blahblahblah(Updated)
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“ric914, post:45, topic:201625”]This doesn’t make any sense

[quote]This is a switch statement because if statements are vulnerable to attacks[/quote][/quote]If statements are just as vulnerable to attacks as switch statements.

The vulnerability is determined by how accessible YOU make things.

Like, example:
http://somesite.com/index.php?doSomething=something

And all you had for the code was:

if (isset($)GET[‘doSomething’])) {
exec($_GET[‘doSomething’]);
}

Obviously something you don’t want to do. There’s no checks to clean input, nothing.
You shouldn’t have to use exec ever anyhow.

Read full topic

item.title: Making a php site with index.php?action=blahblahblah(Updated)
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

MrMoney:

if (blahblah=true;

I don’t know how you could possibly make so many mistakes in that one line of code.

First of all, variables like “blahblah” in your example, are preceded by a dollar sign. So it should be:
if ($blahblah=true;

Second of all, if you’re testing whether something is something else, you use the double equals, not the single equals. Single assigns a value, double checks for equivalency. It should be:
if ($blahblah == true;

Third, if you’re testing whether something evaluates to true, there is no need to see if it equals true. It should be:
if ($blahblah;

Fourth, you end a condition with a close parenthesis. It should be:
if ($blahblah);

Fifth, unless you’re writing it in shorthand, a statement block begins and ends in curly braces. So it should be:
if ($blahblah) {

}

Read full topic
item.source: Making a php site with index.php?action=blahblahblah(Updated)

item.title: Making a php site with index.php?action=blahblahblah(Updated)
item.dc:creator: @MastrChief MastrChief
item.description:
@MastrChief wrote:

Better version of what? Its a simple little function, that can be used for more than just pages, but you’re narrowing it to pages.

[code]

Page

– Some Header –

<?php $Page = $_GET['page']; switch ( $Page ) { case login: // *.php?page=login // You're login shit here break; case logout: // *.php?page=logout // You're logout shit here break; case random: // *.php?page=random // Whatever you want here break; default: // If the page var isn't set // Default page break; } ?>

– Some Footer –

[/code]

Nothing to it.

Read full topic
